title: Does a "catch-all" clause in a trust allow a named beneficiary to withdraw money (probate free) from a bank account not listed?
question: Does a "catch-all" clause in a trust that says all property not listed in schedule of assets is still part of the trust allow a named beneficiary in said trust to withdraw money (directly, avoiding probate) from a bank account not specifically listed in the trust? I cannot find any cases or law that deal with this issue, but I don't see why it wouldn't be allowed. NOTE: I am not interested in pour over wills or anything besides the very specific scenario I described. Pour over wills do not avoid probate and the whole point of my question is to see if probate can be avoided. Please point me to some of the California law or Restatement 3rd of Trusts sections that deal with this, I cannot find anything!
answers:
I regret to inform you and all reading this that I do not know what a "catch-all" clause is.
Nor am I interested in learning what it is, although reading it might be useful.
I cannot imagine a Trust statement being operative that (fairy wand-like) says that "whatever I own is in this Trust, regardless of how it is titled". Written documents are the hallmark of our intent(s).
So assets are EITHER changed to the Trust title OR specifically identified by being listed on Schedule A as items to be owned by the Trustee: Schedule A is why the Heggstad Petition process allows a Court Petition and Order to be used to transfer Assets which are not in the Trust title as of the date of death INTO the Trust because the Settlor's intent is documented by the listing. So what if the Settlor did not get around to changing the title? The choice is either a Heggstad Petition (a motion, limited only to those assets) or a traditional probate (as there may be other issues which need to be handled by the estate's Personal Representative).
If the Assets are not in the Trust title as of the date of death, then were they in the name of the Settlor/Trustee ~ but NOT as Trustee? Just the Settlor individually??
If so, then they were not Trust assets (by the above reasoning).
If so, then they may be collected either by the named beneficiary (if there was one) or if no named beneficiary, by a Probate Code 13101 Affidavit, which has certain requirements.
Before we leap to concluding that a PC 13101 Affidavit was fraudulent, what did its Declarant know in fact? If no probate was then pending, it may not be fraudulent, that Declarant may have assumed responsibility for paying the Deceased Person's debts, and possibly neither of the two of you knows the whole story or Big Picture. Read PC 13101 to see if it applies to your facts.
And please see an Attorney for review of the 'catch-all' phrase and the bank statements and whatever other facts you have.
No. "Catch-all" provision by itself does not allow beneficiary to withdraw money from a bank account. Depending on facts of this matter, Heggsted petition or affidavit may be necessary.

I assume the bank account is solely in the name of the Grantor. If so, the beneficiaries may be able to agree via affidavit to legally have the account brought under the trust. If not, then a Heggstad Petition must be filed with the court. This may be frustrating for you, but there are steps that must be taken when an asset is seemingly unintentionally left off Schedule A.

Make sure the bank account does not have a "pay-on-death" provision. That would change things.

Im assuming you meant the settlor/trustor's name not trustee (the may have been the same). No, there is no right to access and withdraw from the account if it was in the decedent's name alone. The "catch all" you are referring to sounds like an assignment to the trust. That is usually referenced in the trust as I have transferred the assets listed on Schedule A to the Trustee. That creates what is known as an express trust. Court is still required to get the bank to change title under a Heggsted Petition. That said, if the total about outside the trust is less than $150,000, the Trustee (assuming there is a pour-over will which you didn't want to discuss) could use a 13100 Affidavit to pull the assets into the trust.

If the Trustee has died and there is no successor trustee, you need to Petition the Court of appointment of successor trustee unless the court has an alternate mechanism to do so.

If you are spending money of the trust or the decedent's estate without authority, even if you are the only beneficiary, you could have liability to creditor's including the IRS. Be careful and good luck.

"Does a "catch-all" clause in a trust allow a named beneficiary to withdraw money (probate free) from a bank account not listed?" -- No. The trustee (or all beneficiaries) may be able to have the account transferred outside probate via affidavit. Otherwise, approval of a Heggstad petition by the court would be required to bring the account into the trust.
